awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Household and Community Arrangement in a Traditional Society
awd_abstract_narration:
Four out of five Americans now live in cities. As urban populations continue to grow, cities face new challenges to feed their residents in healthy and sustainable ways. One recent solution to this issue has been urban agriculture, which simultaneously "greens" blighted urban areas while making healthy produce accessible to city-dwellers. Though urban farms and gardens have sprung up in dozens of American cities, its ultimate success depends on its long-term implementation over multiple generations. The field of archaeology is well positioned to contribute to this effort because archaeologists can document the successful strategies used by ancient sustainable communities. Some civilizations fed themselves with urban agriculture for centuries, and modern society is beginning to recognize that it can learn a lot about long-term sustainability from those ancient societies. One such civilization, the Maya of Mexico and Central America, is the subject of University of Michigan archaeologist Chelsea Fisher's research into the origins of "intra-settlement or "community" agriculture. Many Maya cities are dispersed or "non-nucleated" with low density of structures: they maintained open spaces in their settlements; evidence suggests that some of these spaces were used for intensive urban agriculture. Though archaeologists recognize that many huge Maya cities of later time periods (ca. 250-900 CE) fed themselves with urban agriculture, it is not fully understood (1) how those sustainable strategies developed in the first place, or (2) how those strategies actually worked at the level of individual households and communities. Until those questions are answered, the potential for what modern society can learn from the ancient Maya example remains underdeveloped.

Fisher's strategy for investigating the origins of Maya urban agriculture is to strip it down to the basics: to study a small community, Tzacauil, that was settled right at the time that the Maya were first learning how to be farmers. Tzacauil, located in the Mexican state of Yucatán, has unique conditions that allow for full archaeological exploration of early (ca. 250 BCE - 250 CE) Maya houses and land-use modifications in the surrounding landscape. Fisher will conduct excavations at nine house groups at Tzacauil in conjunction with rigorous investigation of agricultural features and land-use patterns (e.g., terraces, berms, reservoirs) in the areas between and around houses. Using the archaeological data collected at Tzacauil, Fisher will analyze how multiple generations of Tzacauil families interacted with each other and with their increasingly agricultural landscape. By comparing households' interactions alongside their investments in the landscape, Fisher will explore the development of Tzacauil as an agricultural community. This research is important both for the field of Maya archaeology and for issues of modern community sustainability. Fisher's research at Tzacauil clarifies the early origins of settlement and agriculture in the Maya area, while also providing fine-grained information about how individual households managed the logistics of community agriculture. These insights stand to increase archaeology's ability to contribute long-term data that are potentially instructive for cities interested in promoting community-based sustainability and urban agriculture today.

por.por_cntn:
Cities of the Classic Maya civilization (AD 250-900) fed their populations through a diverse suite of subsistence strategies. One of these strategies was urban agriculture. By inserting gardens and utilizing urban spaces as farmland, huge Maya cities were able to sustain large populations for centuries. As our own modern cities continue to grow, planners and agroecologists are looking to urban agriculture as a potential solution to food security issues – and past societies, like the ancient Maya, offer the possibility to learn how past communities managed urban agricultural landscapes. To maximize what we can learn from the Maya example, we need to improve our understanding of (1) the origins of these particular kinds of human-environment interactions, and (2) how these interactions played out at the household and community levels. Funding from the National Science Foundation enabled the successful completion of Chelsea Fisher’s doctoral dissertation fieldwork, which addresses these areas of inquiry by excavating an early Maya farming community called Tzacauil, located in Yucatán, Mexico.

Tzacauil was a Maya village consisting of less than a dozen houses that were built at the time the Maya were becoming farmers (250 BC – AD 250). The ample open spaces around these houses suggest that early permanent farming villages were maintaining open areas for various land-use strategies within their settlements, as has been observed in later, much larger cities. Project researchers at Tzacauil investigated these houses and the open spaces around them to assess how households interacted with their landscape and with each other during the transition to agriculture.

Tzacauil houses were exposed using horizontal excavation, which allowed for the careful recording of construction techniques, the timing and scale of renovations, and household activities. The project used these lines of evidence to assess the degree to which the builders and occupants of each house group maintained long-term, multigenerational claims to particular places in the settlement, which in turn is an important marker of agricultural investment. Because Tzacauil is such a small settlement, researchers were able to collect data on nearly all of the known houses at the site – contributing to a more comprehensive model of community dynamics than would be possible at a larger settlement where only a small sample of houses could be exposed.

The open areas around Tzacauil’s houses – what researchers called the intra-settlement landscape – were investigated alongside members of the modern Maya community of Yaxunah, who communally own the lands where the archaeological site is located. The Maya people of Yaxunah have intimate knowledge of these lands because they continue to live and farm in similar ecological settings. This ethnographic component of the investigation produced an ecological and cultural inventory for the intra-settlement areas around each of Tzacauil’s houses. These data were then used to select areas for excavations in the open spaces between and around houses. These excavations permitted researchers to recover artifacts, record soil characteristics, and collect soil samples for chemical analysis. Taken together, these lines of evidence were used to infer land-use strategies.

This project contributes a detailed, community-level case study of human-environment interactions during a critical transition to full-time farming. This work supplements research being done at larger and later Maya cities where full-blown urban agriculture has already been documented; at Tzacauil, however, researchers were able to zoom in on an earlier community where the development of these practices could be fully investigated at the village and community level. Additionally, this project brings to the forefront three elements that are often overlooked in Maya studies: (1) the role of small sites in a larger regional picture; (2) the role that small sites play in the support and maintenance of larger cities; and (3) the importance of integrating the study of “vacant” spaces into archaeological approaches to economics, subsistence, and human-environment interactions.

This project advanced participation in scientific research by archaeology students and members of the local Maya community of Yaxunah. Graduate and undergraduate students from the United States and Mexico were taught the scientific skills necessary to run an archaeological project, including excavation, survey, technical drawing, and soil sampling. The project employed 8-14 members of the Yaxunah community on a weekly basis for five months. During their employment, individuals learned techniques in excavation, sampling, and technical drawing. The intra-settlement landscape study, in which both men and women from Yaxunah helped document the ecological and cultural features of Tzacauil, was particularly successful in raising interest in scientific investigations among the local community. Preliminary results from the project were shared in a public presentation in Yaxunah. A report will be submitted to the Mexican government and to the community center of Yaxunah. Presentations at conferences in Mexico and the United States are planned, as are collaborations between project members and scientists at the state university in Yucatán. A dissertation and journal articles are in progress.
